title: Positional Dizziness with Normal Hearing
chief_complaint: I've been getting dizzy for the last few months, especially when I turn over in bed or look up. My hearing seems fine, though my ears sometimes itch or hurt a little.

problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Dizziness upon changing head position (turning in bed, looking up), occasional bilateral ear pain, itchiness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty with daily movements like sleeping/turning in bed.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Identify the cause of the dizziness and resolve the discomfort.

history.present_illness: 54-year-old male reports difficulty with dizziness for the last few months. Dizziness is provoked by turning over in bed or looking up.
history.otologic_history: Reports normal hearing bilaterally. Reports occasional pain and itchiness bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal hearing 250-4000 Hz with a slight sensorineural notch at 3000 Hz, sloping to mild loss at 6000-8000 Hz. Left ear: Normal hearing 250-4000 Hz, sloping to mild loss at 6000-8000 Hz.

numeric_results.Right_AC_Thresholds: 10-15 dB HL (250-2k Hz), 25 dB HL (3k Hz), 15 dB HL (4k Hz), 25 dB HL (8k Hz)
numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: 10-15 dB HL (250-4k Hz), 25 dB HL (8k Hz)

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Reception Thresholds (SRT) are normal and in agreement with the Pure Tone Average (PTA). Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal acoustic reflex thresholds at 500 to 4,000 Hz with ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation. Negative acoustic reflex decay at 500 and 1,000 Hz.

numeric_results.Reflex_Thresholds: Normal (levels not explicitly listed in text, but noted as normal)

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient demonstrates essentially normal hearing sensitivity through the standard speech frequencies (250-4000 Hz) bilaterally, with a mild high-frequency sensorineural slope in the 6000-8000 Hz range and a slight notch at 3000 Hz in the right ear. Speech understanding is excellent, and middle ear function is normal. The audiologic findings do not indicate a retrocochlear pathology or middle ear disease.
counseling_points: Your hearing test today is essentially normal. You have excellent ability to understand speech.
The dizziness you are describing—specifically that it happens when you turn over in bed or look up—is very characteristic of a condition called BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).
This type of dizziness is caused by tiny crystals in the inner ear moving into the wrong canal. It is not related to hearing loss.
I am referring you to an ENT specialist who can perform a simple maneuver (the Epley maneuver) to likely resolve the dizziness.
Regarding the itchiness and pain, the middle ear test was normal, but the ENT can examine your ear canal skin more closely.
notes_for_actor: When describing your dizziness, be very specific that it is triggered by position changes: 'turning over in bed' and 'looking up' (e.g., to a high shelf).
You do not have constant vertigo; it is episodic based on movement.
You believe your hearing is fine, but the itchiness is annoying.
